Twitter Facebook Youtube Instagram Entrar MINHA BAND Tudo em um só lugar para você personalizar seu acesso ENTRAR CADASTRAR Polícia investiga morte do cantor Nahim A Polícia de São Paulo investiga a morte do cantor Nahim, que foi encontrado morto dentro da própria casa. Segundo informações iniciais, ele tenha caído de uma escada e batido a cabeça. O caso é tratado como “morte suspeita". author: Angelica Robinson
title: $18.1 million grant going to Indiana companies for childcare help | wthr.com
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Help is coming to Indiana parents who are having a hard time paying for childcare. The state is giving out $18.1 million in grant money to businesses to help their workers secure care for their children. Gov. Eric Holcomb announced that 64 businesses, community groups and school corporations across the state will receive a portion of the funding. The organizations can then offer that money to families in the form of on-site childcare for employees and childcare tuition benefits. The [Indiana Association for Home and Hospice Care](https://www.iahhc.org/) is one of the organizations receiving grant money. They say the $750,000 will be used as direct scholarships for home care workers to help them reimburse some childcare needs. The program is a partnership with the Indiana Chamber of Commerce and uses a portion of the remaining federal funds from the COVID-19 pandemic. A full list of the grant recipients can be found [here](https://www.in.gov/fssa/carefinder/files/6240-Employee-Sponsored-Child-Care-Fund-Awards.pdf).

author: Jordan Sigler
title: Kirby Smart Destroyed By Fans For 'Dumb' Decision In Georgia-Notre Dame CFP Game
text:
Kirby Smart Destroyed By Fans For ‘Dumb’ Decision In Georgia-Notre Dame CFP Game
No. 2 seed Georgia knew they would be facing adversity on offense after news came out that starting quarterback Carson Beck would miss the College Football Playoff after suffering a season-ending elbow injury in the SEC Championship Game. Gunner Stockton, who led the Bulldogs in the second half of Georgia’s 22-19 win over Texas in the SEC championship, was named the starter against No. 7 Notre Dame in the CFP quarterfinal. Stockton went 9-of-14 for 141 yards in the first half of the Allstate Sugar Bowl at Caesars Superdome in New Orleans. However, the sophomore from Tiger, Georgia, made a…
Read more at athlonsports.com

author: Brandon Chew
title: chevron-right
text: MARQUETTE, Mich., (WPBN/WGTU) -- A northern Michigan man who is a member of The Base, a multi-state white supremacist group, has been convicted on two counts for vandalizing a Michigan synagogue in 2019, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Michigan. Nathan Weeden, 23, of Houghton, was convicted by a federal jury on Thursday of the following charges: "Today's swift conviction sends a strong message that hate will not be tolerated in Michigan's Upper Peninsula," said U.S. Attorney Mark Totten, who was in Marquette for the trial. "No one should be the target of hate because of their race, ethnicity, religion, or any other status," Totten said. "When hateful words become hateful acts, my office will use every tool we have to protect the public and secure justice." Weeden, [Richard Tobin](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/new-jersey-man-sentenced-one-year-and-one-day-prison-conspiring-white-supremacists-vandalize) and [Yousef Barasneh](https://www.justice.gov/usao-edwi/pr/oak-creek-man-who-vandalized-racine-synagogue-pleads-guilty) -- who are all members of The Base -- used an encrypted messaging platform in Sept. 2019 to discuss vandalizing property associated with African Americans and Jewish Americans, according to a news release from the attorney's office. The Southern Poverty Law Center [describes](https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/group/base) The Base as a white nationalist network whose members believe "society should be pushed to collapse so a white ethnostate can arise out of the ruins." The attorney's office said Weeden and his co-conspirators dubbed their plan "Operation Kristallnact," a term in reference to events that took place on Nov. 9-10, 1938, in which German Nazis murdered Jews and destroyed their homes, synagogues, schools and businesses. "Weeden carried out this plan on September 21, 2019, when he spray-painted swastikas and symbols associated with The Base on the outside walls of Temple Jacob," the attorney's office said. On the same night that the Temple Jacob in Hancock, Michigan, was vandalized, members of The Base vandalized a synagogue in Racine, Wisconsin, according to the attorney's office. The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Michigan did not state whether or not a sentencing date had been set for Weeden.
